label.text: This block allows terminal/console access using bluetooth.

block.comment: Set up a single LED with brightness control
Common Cathode: RGB pins connect to positive voltage. Common Anode: RGB pins connect to ground
Set up Red, Green, and Yellow LEDs for patterns
Values: 0-100 for each color
Run a traffic light sequence
Initialize OLED display using I2C. Connect SCL and SDA pins to ESP32. Common sizes: 128x64 or 128x32 pixels.
Initialize OLED with custom width and height. Use this for non-standard display sizes. Standard I2C pins: SCL=22, SDA=21

category.name: ðŸ’¡ NeoPixel
category.comment: Connect NeoPixel data wire to the GPIO pin you specify below

block.comment: Initialize NeoPixel LED strip. PIN: Data pin connected to strip NUMBER: Total LEDs in strip STRIP: Strip ID (use 0 for single strip)

category.comment: Use these blocks to create colors. RGB values go from 0 to 255
LED numbers start at 0. First LED is 0, second is 1, etc.
Brightness from 0 (off) to 255 (maximum bright)

category.name: ðŸ“º Character LCD
category.comment: Connect LCD via I2C using PCF8574 controller. SCL and SDA pins connect to ESP32
Row and column numbers start at 0. First position is (0,0)

block.comment: CLK=Clock, DIO=Data, CS=Chip Select. Count=number of connected matrix modules
Brightness: 0 (dim) to 15 (bright)
Set individual pixel: x and y from 0-7 for single matrix
Initialize TM1637 4-digit 7-segment display. Connect CLK and DIO pins to Microcontroller. Brightness: 0 (dimmest) to 7 (brightest). VCC=3.3/5V, GND=GND
Customize long press time (in milliseconds). Default is 1000ms (1 second)
True if button was quickly pressed and released
True if button was held down for long press time
True while button is being held down (continuously)
How many times button was pressed since last check
How long (in milliseconds) the button is currently held
Call this in your main loop to update button state
Returns raw X-axis value (0-4095)
Returns raw Y-axis value (0-4095)
Returns X position from -100 (left) to 100 (right), 0 is center
Returns Y position from -100 (down) to 100 (up), 0 is center
Common 4x3 keypad with numbers 1-9, *, 0, #
4x4 keypad with numbers, letters A-D
3x3 keypad with numbers 1-9
Custom keypad size - enter your own key layout
Returns the key being pressed, or empty text if no key pressed
Waits until a key is pressed and returns it
Run code when any key is pressed
Collect multiple digits to form a number. Press # to finish
Collect password/PIN. Press # to finish
Set debounce delay in milliseconds (default 50ms)
Setup the remote control receiver. Beacon time helps the remote find this device.
Put this in your main loop to receive remote signals
Triggers only when joystick moves to a specific direction
Triggers when a button is pressed. Choose button (A-F or Joystick) and press type.
Triggers for any button press. Use button name and event type in your code.
Get current joystick position as numbers (-1 to +1)
For sensors with VCC, GND and one DIGITAL pin (e.g., motion sensor, touch sensor, tilt sensor)
For sensors with VCC, GND and one ANALOG pin (e.g., light sensor, sound sensor, potentiometer). Use pins 32-39 for analog
For sensors with VCC, GND, DIGITAL pin and ANALOG pin (e.g., soil moisture, some gas sensors)
Returns value as percentage (0-100%) instead of raw number
Check if analog value is above a threshold. Useful for detecting light/sound levels
Combines both digital and analog readings for smart detection

category.name: ðŸŒ¡ï¸ðŸ’§ Humidity Sensor
category.comment: ðŸ’¡ Tip: Always call "Read DHT sensor" before reading temperature or humidity values!
ðŸŒ¡ï¸ Heat Index: How hot it "feels" with humidity ðŸ’§ Dew Point: Temperature where moisture forms

block.comment: Simple ultrasonic sensor (HC-SR04 compatible)
Ultrasonic sensor with built-in RGB LED
Returns distance in centimeters (2-400 cm range)
Returns distance in inches
Set RGB LED color (0-255 for each)
Set measurement timeout in microseconds (default 30000)
Returns raw echo time in microseconds

category.name: ðŸ›°ï¸ GPS
category.comment: ðŸ“¡ Always call "Update GPS" in a loop to read new data from the GPS module!
ðŸ“ Latitude: North/South position ðŸ“ Longitude: East/West position â›°ï¸ Altitude: Height above sea level Check "Has GPS fix?" first!
ðŸ§­ Course: Direction in degrees (0-360) ðŸ§­ Direction: N, NE, E, SE, S, SW, W, NW

category.name: â¤ï¸ Heart Sensor
category.comment: ðŸ’“ Red LED: Measures heart rate ðŸ©¸ Infrared LED: Measures blood oxygen Always call "Read sensor" before getting values!
â¤ï¸ Heart Rate: Beats per minute (BPM) ðŸ« SpO2: Blood oxygen level (95-100% normal)
âš¡ LED Current: 0 to 50 mA Higher = brighter but uses more power Default: 11 mA works well

category.name: ðŸŽ¯ Motion Sensor
category.comment: ðŸ“Š Accelerometer measures movement and tilt. Values in m/sÂ²
ðŸ”„ Gyroscope measures rotation speed. Values in rad/s
ðŸ“ Kalman Filter: More accurate, removes noise ðŸ“ Complementary: Faster, good for most uses Pitch: Forward/back tilt Roll: Left/right tilt

category.name: ðŸŒ¡ï¸ Digital Thermometer
category.comment: ðŸ’¡ Tip: Use index 0 for first sensor, 1 for second, etc.

block.comment: MFRC522 RFID reader with SPI interface
Check if a card/tag is near the reader
Wait for card with timeout in seconds (0 = wait forever)
Returns card UID as text (e.g., "A1:B2:C3:D4")
Returns UID as list of bytes
Check if current card matches this UID
Read 16 bytes from block (blocks 0-63 for 1K cards)
Write text to block (max 16 characters)
Read text from multiple blocks
Write long text across multiple blocks
Authenticate before read/write (default key A)
Set authentication key (default: FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF)
Rotary encoder with CLK, DT, and optional SW (button) pins
Rotary encoder without button (2-pin version)
Get current encoder position (can be negative)
Get change since last read (positive = clockwise, negative = counterclockwise)
Wait for button press with timeout in seconds (0 = wait forever)
True if rotated clockwise since last check
True if rotated counterclockwise since last check
Constrain encoder value within min and max range
Multiply rotation by scale factor (e.g., 5 = count by 5s)
Connect SDA to pin 21 and SCL to pin 22 on ESP32. This sensor measures temperature, pressure and altitude!
Higher accuracy takes more time but gives better readings. Good for precise measurements!
Set baseline pressure (in Pa) for accurate altitude calculation. Default is 101325 Pa (sea level)
For 180Â° servo motors. Connect signal wire to pin, red to 5V, brown to GND
For 360Â° continuous rotation servo. Connect signal wire to pin
Angle: 0-180 degrees. 90 is center position
Sweep servo back and forth. Delay in milliseconds
Move smoothly to angle. Speed: 1-20 (higher is faster)
Speed: 0-100%. Higher is faster
Turn off servo signal to save power and allow free movement
Turn on servo signal after detaching
Connect motor to L298N driver. IN1/IN2 control direction, EN controls speed
Speed: 0-100%
Run motor for specified seconds then stop
Connect your stepper motor: IN1-IN4 to ESP32 GPIO pins. Use different Motor IDs (0-9) for multiple motors. 28BYJ-48 uses 2048 steps per revolution.
Rotate motor by angle: 90 degrees = quarter turn, 180 degrees = half turn, 360 degrees = full turn
Move by exact steps: 1 full rotation = steps per revolution. 28BYJ-48: 2048 steps = 360 degrees. Use for precise control.
Go to absolute position: 0 degrees = starting position. Motor remembers where it is. Great for returning to positions.
Choose easy speed presets: Very Slow = careful movements, Fast = quick actions
Set exact speed in RPM: RPM = Rotations Per Minute. 28BYJ-48: 1-15 RPM typical. Higher = faster (may skip steps)
Smooth rotation with acceleration: Smooth = gradual speed changes, Normal = standard movement, Quick = fast start and stop
WARNING: This blocks your code! Use only when you want continuous rotation. Put a Stop block to halt spinning.
Emergency stop: Halts motor immediately and turns off all coils
Fun dance pattern! Motor moves back and forth. Great for testing your setup.
Get current position in degrees. Returns number from 0 degrees onwards.
Check if motor is moving. Returns true or false.
Reset position to 0 degrees. Current position becomes new start.

category.name: ðŸŽµ RTTTL Player
category.comment: Play famous melodies! Choose from pre-loaded popular songs.
Play your own RTTTL string! Format: name:settings:notes Example: MySong:d=4,o=5,b=140:8c,8d,8e

block.field:
ðŸŽµ TEXT TO MUSIC! ðŸŽµ Write music using letters! c = Do d = Re e = Mi f = Fa g = Sol a = La b = Ti p = Rest (silent) Numbers before notes = how fast: 8c = quick 4c = normal 2c = long Make it higher: add 6 after note, Example: c6 = high Do Simple song: "Song:d=4,o=5,b=120:c,e,g,c6" Change the letters to make new music!
ðŸŽ¼ Infinity Learning Space ðŸŽ¼

category.comment: Play individual musical notes! Choose note, octave, and duration. Great for making your own melodies!
Set buzzer volume (0-100%). Lower values = quieter sound.

block.comment: Connect ESP32 to WiFi network. Wait for connection before using HTTP blocks
Create WiFi hotspot. Others can connect to your ESP32
Start web server on ESP32. Others can access via IP address
Create a web page at specific URL path (e.g., /home, /led, /sensor)
Get data from URL. Example: /led?state=on gets "state" value
Download data from a website or API
Send data to a website or API
Download file and save to ESP32 storage
Convert JSON text to usable data
Enable real-time communication. Updates instantly without refresh
Setup email connection. For Gmail, use an App Password (not your regular password)
Send an email to someone
Send email and specify who it's from
Check if email was sent successfully
Get the error message if email failed
Send email to multiple people at once
Close email connection
Get current time from the internet. Make sure WiFi is connected first! You can adjust timezone offset (e.g., +5.5 for India, -5 for EST)
Setup MQTT connection. Connect to WiFi first! Use a free broker like broker.hivemq.com or test.mosquitto.org
Setup MQTT with username and password (for private brokers)
Connect to MQTT broker
Send a message to a topic. Anyone subscribed to this topic will receive it!
Send message with Quality of Service (QoS). Higher QoS = more reliable delivery
Subscribe to a topic to receive messages. Use wildcards: + for one level, # for multiple levels
Set what to do when a message arrives. The 'topic' and 'message' variables will be available inside
Check for new messages (call this regularly in a loop)
Get the topic of the last received message
Get the content of the last received message
Check if connected to MQTT broker
Disconnect from MQTT broker
Send keepalive ping to broker
For 4-wheel PCA9685 mode: Setup I2C and set channels (0-15) for each wheel
For 2-wheel PCA9685 mode: Setup I2C and set channels (0-15) for left and right wheels
Set GPIO pins for 4-wheel Direct mode. Use PWM-capable pins!
Set GPIO pins for 2-wheel Direct mode. Use PWM-capable pins!
Calibrate servo range if needed. Standard servos: 500-2500Î¼s
Move forward - works in all modes
Move backward - works in all modes
Rotate left - works in all modes
Rotate right - works in all modes
Stop all wheels
Curve while moving. Turn sharpness: 0=gentle, 100=sharp
Curve while moving. Turn sharpness: 0=gentle, 100=sharp
Drift left - works best in 4-wheel mode
Drift right - works best in 4-wheel mode
Control single wheel in 4-wheel mode. Speed: -100 to 100
Control single wheel in 2-wheel mode. Speed: -100 to 100
Choose configuration and driver type. L298N: needs enable pins. DRV8833: only needs IN pins
Set pins for L298N driver with 4 motors. Each motor uses 3 pins: ENA/ENB (speed), IN1/IN3 (direction 1), IN2/IN4 (direction 2)
Set pins for L298N driver with 2 motors. Each motor uses 3 pins: ENA/ENB (speed), IN1/IN3 (direction 1), IN2/IN4 (direction 2)
Set pins for DRV8833 driver with 4 motors. Each motor uses 2 pins: IN1/IN3 (direction 1), IN2/IN4 (direction 2)
Set pins for DRV8833 driver with 2 motors. Each motor uses 2 pins: IN1/IN3 (direction 1), IN2/IN4 (direction 2)
Enable mirror mode if motors rotate in wrong direction. Try enabling left or right mirror if car doesn't go straight
Move DC motor car forward
Move DC motor car backward
Rotate DC motor car left
Rotate DC motor car right
Stop all DC motors
Curve while moving forward. Turn sharpness: 0=gentle, 100=sharp
Curve while moving forward. Turn sharpness: 0=gentle, 100=sharp
Drift left - works best in 4-wheel mode
Drift right - works best in 4-wheel mode
Control single DC motor in 4-wheel mode. Speed: -100 to 100
Control single DC motor in 2-wheel mode. Speed: -100 to 100
